column1: has a cost.[23][24][25] Manufacturing activities that cause air pollution impose health and clean-up costs on the whole of society
column2: whereas the neighbors of an individual who chooses to fire-proof his home may benefit from a reduced risk of a fire spreading to their own homes. A manufacturing activity that causes air pollution is an example of a negative externality in production. A negative externality in production occurs “when a firm’s production reduces the well-being of others who are not compensated by the firm."[26] For example
column3: if a laundry firm exists near a polluting steel manufacturing firm
column4: there will be increased costs for the laundry firm because of the dirt and smoke produced by the steel manufacturing firm.[27] If external costs exist
column5: such as those created by pollution
column6: the manufacturer will choose to produce more of the product than would be produced if the manufacturer were required to pay all associated environmental costs. Because responsibility or consequence for self-directed action lies partly outside the self
column7: an element of externalization is involved. If there are external benefits
column9: less of the good may be produced than would be the case if the producer were to receive payment for the external benefits to others. However
column10: goods and services that involve negative externalities in production
column11: such as those that produce pollution
column12: tend to be over-produced and underpriced since the externality is not being priced into the market.[26]

column1: can also create costs for the firms producing the pollution. Sometimes firms choose
column2: or are forced by regulation
column3: to reduce the amount of pollution that they are producing. The associated costs of doing this are called abatement costs
column4: or marginal abatement costs if measured by each additional unit.[28] In 2005 pollution abatement capital expenditures and operating costs in the US amounted to nearly $27 billion.[29]

column1: derives some indirect utility from pollution
column2: otherwise there would be no incentive to pollute. This utility comes from the consumption of goods and services that create pollution. Therefore
column3: it is important that policymakers attempt to balance these indirect benefits with the costs of pollution in order to achieve an efficient outcome.[30]

column1: visual comparison of the free market and socially optimal outcomes.
is possible to use environmental economics to determine which level of pollution is deemed the social optimum. For economists
column2: pollution is an “external cost and occurs only when one or more individuals suffer a loss of welfare
column3: ” however
column4: there exists a socially optimal level of pollution at which welfare is maximized.[31] This is because consumers derive utility from the good or service manufactured
column5: which will outweigh the social cost of pollution until a certain point. At this point the damage of one extra unit of pollution to society
column7: is exactly equal to the marginal benefit of consuming one more unit of the good or service.[32]

column2: or other negative externalities in production
column3: the free market equilibrium will not account for the costs of pollution on society. If the social costs of pollution are higher than the private costs incurred by the firm
column4: then the true supply curve will be higher. The point at which the social marginal cost and market demand intersect gives the socially optimal level of pollution. At this point
column5: the quantity will be lower and the price will be higher in comparison to the free market equilibrium.[32] Therefore
column6: the free market outcome could be considered a market failure because it “does not maximize efficiency”.[26]

column2: is a dictum which summarizes a traditional approach to pollution management whereby sufficiently diluted pollution is not harmful.[69][70] It is well-suited to some other modern
column3: locally scoped applications such as laboratory safety procedure and hazardous material release emergency management. But it assumes that the dilutant is in virtually unlimited supply for the application or that resulting dilutions are acceptable in all cases.

column1: simple treatment for environmental pollution on a wider scale might have had greater merit in earlier centuries when physical survival was often the highest imperative

column4: advances have enabled measurement of concentrations not possible before. column5: consideration of the environment beyond direct impact on human beings has gained prominence.
